In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Integer = 3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        error("timezone_bumper can only be applied to DateTime objects, not Date objects.")
    end
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```

This function `timezone_bumper` takes a `DateTime` object and an optional integer `bump` (defaulting to 3 hours). It then increases the timestamp of the `DateTime` by `bump` hours using the `Dates.Hour` type, which is a constructor for time intervals in Julia's date-time system. If you try to pass a `Date` object, an error will be thrown as specified.
